In an ionic bond, a metal atom donates an electron to a nonmetallic atom, forming a positive ion (cation) and a negative ion (anion). As a result of losing an electron, the number of electrons in the cation decreases, causing the electron cloud to shrink. This reduction in the size of the electron cloud leads to a decrease in the ionic radius of the cation compared to its neutral atom.
